bioghist.p: Ida Kaplan Langman (1904-1991) was born in the Ukraine. While she was still an infant, the Kaplan family immigrated to the United States and settled in Philadelphia. Kaplan married Oscar Langman in 1928. She received a teaching certificate from the Philadelphia Normal School and taught in the public schools, ending her teaching career as the Board of Education's first museum teacher assigned to the Academy of Natural Sciences. While working as a teacher, she pursued her graduate studies at the University of Pennsylvania, earning a master's degree in botany in 1945. She worked as a botanist, bibliographer, and author. In 1964, she published A Selected Guide to the Literature on the Flowering Plants of Mexico, her best known work. She also worked on a bibliography of worldwide botanical literature for the Hunt Botanical Library at Carnegie-Mellon.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of professional and some personal correspondence, most of it incoming, of Ida Langman. Much of the correspondence relates to Langman's compilation of bibliographies of Mexican flora and of worldwide botanical literature. Some of the correspondence is in Spanish.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Historical Society of Pennsylvania: Ida Kaplan Langman scrapbook (collection 3038); Carnegie Mellon University, Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation: Ida Kaplan Langman papers (Collection #179).
